messages.content:
You are going to play a text adventure game. All of the user's input
represents text printed by the game. Your output will be interpreted
as commands issued to the game. However, the game will ignore
anything you put in parentheses. Use parentheticals to record your
thoughts as you think step-by-step through these instructions before
you decide what move to make. Every time you enter a new room, begin
your next thought by listing what exits you see.

The game you will be playing is randomly generated, but all games
follow the same simple template. Your goal is to prepare and eat a
meal. To do this, you will perform the following, three-phase
procedure.

# Phase I: Find the kitchen

Explore the map until you locate the kitchen. Use compass commands
`N`, `S`, `E`, and `W` to move around. There may be doors in your
way. Use the command `OPEN <adjective> DOOR` to open them,
substituting whatever adjective you see in the room description.

When you explore, pay careful attention to any occurrence of "north",
"south", "east", or "west" in a room description. These words always
indicate room exits. Explore all exits until you've located
everything you need.

During this phase, make a note of any items you come across, but do
not pick any of them up.

# Phase II: Search for ingredients

Once you find the kitchen, use the command `READ COOKBOOK`. The
cookbook will contain a list of ingredients, and then a list of
directions for preparation. Right now, just pay attention to the
list of ingredients. Don't worry about preparation until Phase III.

Next, use the command `I` to list your inventory. You may already be
carrying some of the ingredients you need. If you are carrying
anything that you *don't* need, use the `DROP` command to drop it.
You may find some items in your inventory that you didn't pick up,
which were there at the start of the game. This is normal.

Third, use the command `OPEN FRIDGE`. If the fridge contains any
ingredients you need, use the `GET` command to pick them up.

Now, figure out what ingredients you are still missing, and then
continue exploring the map until you find them.

Pick up only the ingredients that the recipe calls for. Pay
attention to their entire description. For example, if the recipe
calls for a red pepper, don't pick up a yellow pepper unles the
recipe needs that too.

If you try to pick something up and the game tells you, "You're
carrying too many things already", you've messed up: either you're
carrying something you don't need, or you don't need the thing
you're trying to pick up.  Check your inventory again (use `I`),
compare your inventory against the recipe, and `DROP` any
unnecessary items.

If you get lost or stuck in a loop while exploring in Phase II,
remember the principles from Phase I: look for "north", "south",
"east", and "west" in room descriptions to make sure you haven't
overlooked any exits. If you notice a closed door, that's certainly
a way you haven't explored yet.

# Phase III: Prepare your meal

Once you have all your ingredients, return to the kitchen. Now
`READ COOKBOOK` again, and then check your inventory again.
Double-check that your inventory contains all the required
ingredients and nothing else. If you made a mistake, return to
phase II and correct it.

Now you are ready to follow the directions in the cookbook. Each
step except the last one in the list of directions is either a
cutting step, or a cooking step. A cutting step calls for you either
to *slice*, *dice*, or *chop* an ingredient. A cooking step calls
for you either to *roast*, *fry*, or *grill* an ingredient.

Determine if any steps involve cutting. If and only if you need to
cut anything, use `GET KNIFE` to pick up the knife. You might have
to drop something first to make room for the knife in your inventory.

Now, follow the directions in order and follow them exactly. Use the
following commands:

* If the cookbook says to *slice* an ingredient, use `SLICE <ingredient> WITH KNIFE`.
* If the cookbook says to *dice* an ingredient, use `DICE <ingredient> WITH KNIFE`.
* If the cookbook says to *chop* an ingredient, use `CHOP <ingredient> WITH KNIFE`.
* If the cookbook says to *roast* an ingredient, use `COOK <ingredient> WITH OVEN`.
* If the cookbook says to *fry* an ingredient, use `COOK <ingredient> WITH STOVE`.
* If the cookbook says to *grill* an ingredient, use `COOK <ingredient> WITH BBQ`.

Be careful to use the right verb for cutting and the right appliance
for cooking! If you slice something that you should have diced or
chopped, or if you roast something that you should have fried or
grilled, you'll lose the game. Also be sure not to cook any
ingredient more than once, or you'll burn it.

Everything you need for meal preparation is in the kitchen, except
for the BBQ. The BBQ is in the backyard. So, if you have to grill
something, you will have to go to the backyard first and then return
to the kitchen afterward. After you get back to the kitchen, you
should `READ COOKBOOK` again so you can remember where you left off.

The final step in the list of directions will be "prepare meal", so
once you have done everything else, use `PREPARE MEAL` to put the
ingredients together; make sure you're still holding them all. You
can drop the knife now if you need to. Finally, use the command
`EAT MEAL` to win the game, and then `QUIT`.

             |  \  _  |  \ /      \ |       \ |  \      |       \

             | $$/  $\| $$| $$  | $$| $$__| $$| $$      | $$  | $$
             | $$  $$$\ $$| $$  | $$| $$    $$| $$      | $$  | $$
             | $$ $$\$$\$$| $$  | $$| $$$$$$$\| $$      | $$  | $$
             | $$$$  \$$$$| $$__/ $$| $$  | $$| $$_____ | $$__/ $$
             | $$$    \$$$ \$$    $$| $$  | $$| $$     \| $$    $$
              \$$      \$$  \$$$$$$  \$$   \$$ \$$$$$$$$ \$$$$$$$ 

You are hungry! Let's cook a delicious meal. Check the cookbook in the kitchen for the recipe. Once done, enjoy your meal!

-= Backyard =-
You find yourself in a backyard.

You make out a patio table. But the thing is empty. You see a patio chair. Wow, isn't TextWorld just the best? The patio chair is stylish. But there isn't a thing on it. You see a gleam over in a corner, where you can see a BBQ.

There is a closed screen door leading south. There is a closed wooden door leading west. There is an exit to the east. Don't worry, there is no door.

>

(I see exits to the south, east, and west. I'm in Phase I, searching for the kitchen. I've started the game in the backyard, where the BBQ is. That isn't important right now, but I'll remember it for later in case I need to grill something. Let's try the east exit first.) E

-= Garden =-
You've entered a garden.



There is an exit to the west.

>
(I see an exit to the west. Looks like this is a dead end with nothing useful, so I'll go back west) W

-= Backyard =-
You find yourself in a backyard.

You make out a patio table. But the thing is empty. You see a patio chair. Wow, isn't TextWorld just the best? The patio chair is stylish. But there isn't a thing on it. You see a gleam over in a corner, where you can see a BBQ.

There is a closed screen door leading south. There is a closed wooden door leading west. There is an exit to the east. Don't worry, there is no door.

>
(I see exits to the south, east, and west.  I'll search westward next, but first I need to open the door in my way) OPEN WOODEN DOOR

You open wooden door.

>
(Now that the door is open, the path west is clear) W

-= Shed =-
Welcome to the shed. You can barely contain your excitement.

You can make out a closed toolbox here. You can see a workbench. The workbench is wooden. Looks like someone's already been here and taken everything off it, though. You swear loudly.

There is an open wooden door leading east.

>
(I see an exit to the east. Another dead end. The toolbox and workbench aren't useful.) E

-= Backyard =-
You find yourself in a backyard.

You make out a patio table. But the thing is empty. You see a patio chair. Wow, isn't TextWorld just the best? The patio chair is stylish. But there isn't a thing on it. You see a gleam over in a corner, where you can see a BBQ.

There is a closed screen door leading south. There is an open wooden door leading west. There is an exit to the east. Don't worry, there is no door.

>
(I see exits to the south, east, and west.  I've checked east and west, so only south remains. There's another door there I need to open.) OPEN SCREEN DOOR

You open screen door.

>
(Now my way south is clear.) S

-= Kitchen =-
You've just shown up in a kitchen.

You make out a closed fridge in the corner. You can see a closed conventional looking oven in the corner. You scan the room, seeing a table. The table is massive. But the thing hasn't got anything on it. What, you think everything in TextWorld should have stuff on it? You make out a counter. The counter is vast. On the counter you can see a cookbook and a knife. There's something strange about this being here, but you can't put your finger on it. You see a stove. However, the stove, like an empty stove, has nothing on it.

There is an open screen door leading north. There is a closed frosted-glass door leading west. There is an exit to the east. There is an exit to the south.

>
(I see exits to the north, south, east, and west. I found the kitchen, so I'm in Phase II now. The first thing to do in Phase II is read the cookbook.) READ COOKBOOK

You open the copy of "Cooking: A Modern Approach (3rd Ed.)" and start reading:

Recipe #1
---------
Gather all following ingredients and follow the directions to prepare this tasty meal.

Ingredients:
  black pepper
  chicken leg
  milk

Directions:
  roast the chicken leg
  prepare meal


>
(Okay, I'm looking for a black papper, a chicken leg, and milk. Do I already have any of that?) I

You are carrying nothing.

>
(No, there's nothing in my inventory. So there's nothing I need to drop, but three ingredients to search for. The fridge is the first place to search.) OPEN FRIDGE

You open the fridge, revealing a raw chicken leg and a raw chicken wing.

>
(That raw chicken leg is one of my three ingredients, so I should pick it up. The wing isn't an ingredient, so I'll ignore that.) GET RAW CHICKEN LEG

You take the chicken leg from the fridge.

Your score has just gone up by one point.

>

(That's one ingredient down, two I'm still searching for. I see there are exits from here in all four directions, but I've already explored everything to the north. Let's try west.)  OPEN FROSTED-GLASS DOOR

You open frosted-glass door.

>
(Now my path west is clear.) W

-= Pantry =-
You arrive in a pantry. A normal one. The room seems oddly familiar, as though it were only superficially different from the other rooms in the building.

You see a shelf. The shelf is wooden. On the shelf you can see a flour.

There is an open frosted-glass door leading east.

>
(I see an exit to the east. I don't need flour, so there's nothing useful here, and it's a dead end.) E

-= Kitchen =-
You've just shown up in a kitchen.

You make out an opened fridge in the corner. The fridge contains a raw chicken wing. You can see a closed conventional looking oven in the corner. You scan the room, seeing a table. The table is massive. But the thing hasn't got anything on it. What, you think everything in TextWorld should have stuff on it? You make out a counter. The counter is vast. On the counter you can see a cookbook and a knife. There's something strange about this being here, but you can't put your finger on it. You see a stove. However, the stove, like an empty stove, has nothing on it.

There is an open screen door leading north. There is an open frosted-glass door leading west. There is an exit to the east. There is an exit to the south.

>
(I see exits to the north, south, east, and west. The east and south exits are still unexplored. Let's go east.) E

-= Livingroom =-
You arrive in a livingroom. An ordinary kind of place.

You scan the room, seeing a sofa. But the thing hasn't got anything on it.

There is an exit to the south. You don't like doors? Why not try going west, that entranceway is not blocked by one.

>
(I see exits to the south and west. There's nothing useful here, but there's an unexplored exit to the south.) S

-= Bedroom =-
You are in a bedroom. It seems to be pretty typical here. The room is well lit.

You can make out a bed. The bed is large. The bed appears to be empty.

There is an exit to the north. Don't worry, there is no door. You don't like doors? Why not try going west, that entranceway is not blocked by one.

>
(I see exits to the north and west. Again nothing useful here, but another unexplored exit to the west.) W

-= Corridor =-
You've entered a corridor. You decide to start listing off everything you see in the room, as if you were in a text adventure.



There is a closed front door leading west. There is an exit to the east. Don't worry, there is no door. You don't like doors? Why not try going north, that entranceway is not blocked by one. There is an exit to the south. Don't worry, there is no door.

>

(I see exits to the north, east, and west. In my last three turns I went east, south, and west from the kitchen, so that north exit probably takes me back to the kitchen. West seems like the most promising direction for further exploration, but I need to open the door first.) OPEN FRONT DOOR

You open front door.

>
(Now my way west is clear.) W

-= Driveway =-
You have entered the most typical of all possible driveways.



There is an open front door leading east. You don't like doors? Why not try going west, that entranceway is not blocked by one.

>
(I see exits to the east and west. There's nothing useful here, but there's an explored exit to the west.) W

-= Street =-
You are in a street. A normal kind of place.



There is a closed sliding door leading north. There is an exit to the east. Don't worry, there is no door.

>
(I see exits to the north and east. Again nothing useful here, but there's a door to the north.) OPEN SLIDING DOOR

You open sliding door.

>
(Now my way north is clear.) N

-= Supermarket =-
You arrive in a supermarket. A standard one. You begin to take stock of what's in the room.

What's that over there? It looks like it's a showcase. The showcase is metallic. On the showcase you make out a black pepper, some milk, a red hot pepper and a salt.

There is an open sliding door leading south.

>
(I see an exit to the south. Jackpot! This room has both of the ingredients I'm still searching for. First, the black pepper.) GET BLACK PEPPER

You take the black pepper from the showcase.

Your score has just gone up by one point.

>
(I also need the milk.) GET MILK

You take the milk from the showcase.

Your score has just gone up by one point.

>
(I don't need the red hot pepper or the salt. I have all my ingredients now, which means I'm in Phase III and should return to the kitchen by going back the way I came.) S

-= Street =-
You are in a street. A normal kind of place.



There is an open sliding door leading north. There is an exit to the east. Don't worry, there is no door.

>
(I see exits to the north and east. The house is back east.) E

-= Driveway =-
You have entered the most typical of all possible driveways.



There is an open front door leading east. You don't like doors? Why not try going west, that entranceway is not blocked by one.

>
(I see exits to the east and west. I'll go east again to re-enter the house.) E

-= Corridor =-
You've entered a corridor. You decide to start listing off everything you see in the room, as if you were in a text adventure.



There is an open front door leading west. There is an exit to the east. Don't worry, there is no door. You don't like doors? Why not try going north, that entranceway is not blocked by one. There is an exit to the south. Don't worry, there is no door.

>
(I see exits to the north, east, and west. Okay, now I'm back in this corridor. I speculated earlier that north would be a shortcut back to the kitchen.) N

-= Kitchen =-
You've just shown up in a kitchen.

You make out an opened fridge in the corner. The fridge contains a raw chicken wing. You can see a closed conventional looking oven in the corner. You scan the room, seeing a table. The table is massive. But the thing hasn't got anything on it. What, you think everything in TextWorld should have stuff on it? You make out a counter. The counter is vast. On the counter you can see a cookbook and a knife. There's something strange about this being here, but you can't put your finger on it. You see a stove. However, the stove, like an empty stove, has nothing on it.

There is an open screen door leading north. There is an open frosted-glass door leading west. There is an exit to the east. There is an exit to the south.

>
(I see exits to the north, south, east, and west. I'm back in the kitchen, so it's time to re-read the cookbook.) READ COOKBOOK

You open the copy of "Cooking: A Modern Approach (3rd Ed.)" and start reading:

Recipe #1
---------
Gather all following ingredients and follow the directions to prepare this tasty meal.

Ingredients:
  black pepper
  chicken leg
  milk

Directions:
  roast the chicken leg
  prepare meal


>
(Now I'll check my inventory to double-check that I have all the ingredients.) I

You are carrying:
  some milk
  a black pepper
  a raw chicken leg

>

(The ingredients I need are a black pepper, chicken leg, and milk. That exactly matches my inventory, so that means I did everything right so far and can proceed with the directions. Sice none of the directions involve cutting, I can ignore the knife. The first direction says to roast the chicken leg. When I need to roast something, I use the oven. I mustn't use the stove or the BBQ; I'd lose the game if I did that.)  COOK RAW CHICKEN LEG WITH OVEN

You roasted the chicken leg.

Your score has just gone up by one point.

>
(Okay, checking my inventory one more time: I should still be holding all the now-cooked ingredients.) I

You are carrying:
  some milk
  a black pepper
  a roasted chicken leg

>

(Right. I'm still holding the now-roasted chicken leg, as well as milk and the black pepper which didn't need any preparation. Now, the final step in the directions is to prepare the meal, and I should be ready for that.) PREPARE MEAL

Adding the meal to your inventory.

Your score has just gone up by one point.

>
(Finally, I can eat the meal. This should win the game.) EAT MEAL

You eat the meal. Not bad.

Your score has just gone up by one point.


                                                       *** The End ***

You scored 6 out of a possible 6, in 35 turn(s).


Would you like to QUIT?
>
QUIT

Well done! Now play a new game. Your instructions are the same as before:

You are going to play a text adventure game. All of the user's input
represents text printed by the game. Your output will be interpreted
as commands issued to the game. However, the game will ignore
anything you put in parentheses. Use parentheticals to record your
thoughts as you think step-by-step through these instructions before
you decide what move to make. Every time you enter a new room, begin
your next thought by listing what exits you see.

The game you will be playing is randomly generated, but all games
follow the same simple template. Your goal is to prepare and eat a
meal. To do this, you will perform the following, three-phase
procedure.

# Phase I: Find the kitchen

Explore the map until you locate the kitchen. Use compass commands
`N`, `S`, `E`, and `W` to move around. There may be doors in your
way. Use the command `OPEN <adjective> DOOR` to open them,
substituting whatever adjective you see in the room description.

When you explore, pay careful attention to any occurrence of "north",

everything you need.

During this phase, make a note of any items you come across, but do

# Phase II: Search for ingredients

Once you find the kitchen, use the command `READ COOKBOOK`. The

list of ingredients. Don't worry about preparation until Phase III.

Next, use the command `I` to list your inventory. You may already be
carrying some of the ingredients you need. If you are carrying
anything that you *don't* need, use the `DROP` command to drop it.
You may find some items in your inventory that you didn't pick up,
which were there at the start of the game. This is normal.

Third, use the command `OPEN FRIDGE`. If the fridge contains any
ingredients you need, use the `GET` command to pick them up.

Now, figure out what ingredients you are still missing, and then
continue exploring the map until you find them.

Pick up only the ingredients that the recipe calls for. Pay
attention to their entire description. For example, if the recipe
calls for a red pepper, don't pick up a yellow pepper unles the
recipe needs that too.

If you try to pick something up and the game tells you, "You're
carrying too many things already", you've messed up: either you're
carrying something you don't need, or you don't need the thing
you're trying to pick up.  Check your inventory again (use `I`),
compare your inventory against the recipe, and `DROP` any

If you get lost or stuck in a loop while exploring in Phase II,
remember the principles from Phase I: look for "north", "south",
"east", and "west" in room descriptions to make sure you haven't
overlooked any exits. If you notice a closed door, that's certainly
a way you haven't explored yet.

# Phase III: Prepare your meal

Once you have all your ingredients, return to the kitchen. Now
`READ COOKBOOK` again, and then check your inventory again.
Double-check that your inventory contains all the required
ingredients and nothing else. If you made a mistake, return to
phase II and correct it.

Now you are ready to follow the directions in the cookbook. Each
step except the last one in the list of directions is either a
cutting step, or a cooking step. A cutting step calls for you either
to *slice*, *dice*, or *chop* an ingredient. A cooking step calls
for you either to *roast*, *fry*, or *grill* an ingredient.

Determine if any steps involve cutting. If and only if you need to
cut anything, use `GET KNIFE` to pick up the knife. You might have
to drop something first to make room for the knife in your inventory.

Now, follow the directions in order and follow them exactly. Use the
following commands:

* If the cookbook says to *slice* an ingredient, use `SLICE <ingredient> WITH KNIFE`.
* If the cookbook says to *dice* an ingredient, use `DICE <ingredient> WITH KNIFE`.
* If the cookbook says to *chop* an ingredient, use `CHOP <ingredient> WITH KNIFE`.
* If the cookbook says to *roast* an ingredient, use `COOK <ingredient> WITH OVEN`.
* If the cookbook says to *fry* an ingredient, use `COOK <ingredient> WITH STOVE`.
* If the cookbook says to *grill* an ingredient, use `COOK <ingredient> WITH BBQ`.

Be careful to use the right verb for cutting and the right appliance
for cooking! If you slice something that you should have diced or
chopped, or if you roast something that you should have fried or
grilled, you'll lose the game. Also be sure not to cook any
ingredient more than once, or you'll burn it.

Everything you need for meal preparation is in the kitchen, except
for the BBQ. The BBQ is in the backyard. So, if you have to grill
something, you will have to go to the backyard first and then return
to the kitchen afterward. After you get back to the kitchen, you
should `READ COOKBOOK` again so you can remember where you left off.

The final step in the list of directions will be "prepare meal", so
once you have done everything else, use `PREPARE MEAL` to put the
ingredients together; make sure you're still holding them all. You
can drop the knife now if you need to. Finally, use the command

(I see exits to the west and south. Let's try west first, but I need to open the door.) OPEN COMMERCIAL GLASS DOOR

You open commercial glass door.


>
(Now my way west is clear.) W

-= Supermarket =-
This might come as a shock to you, but you've just walked into a supermarket.

You see a showcase. You shudder, but continue examining the showcase. On the showcase you see a raw white tuna and a white onion.

There is an open commercial glass door leading east.


>
(I see an exit to the east. This room doesn't seem to have anything to do with the kitchen, so I'll go back east.) E

-= Street =-
You find yourself in a street. An usual kind of place. You try to gain information on your surroundings by using a technique you call "looking."



There is an open commercial glass door leading west. There is an exit to the south. Don't worry, there is no door.


>
(I see exits to the west and south. Since west didn't lead me to the kitchen, I'll try going south.) S

-= Driveway =-
Look at you, bigshot, walking into a driveway like it isn't some huge deal.



There is a closed front door leading south. There is an exit to the north.


>
(I see exits to the north and south. The house is probably to the south, so I need to open the door first.) OPEN FRONT DOOR

You open front door.


>
(Now my way south is clear.) S

-= Livingroom =-
You're now in a livingroom.

You can see a sofa. However, the sofa, like an empty sofa, has nothing on it.

There is an open front door leading north. There is an exit to the south. There is an exit to the west. Don't worry, there is no door.


>
(I see exits to the north, south, and west. Let's try west first.) W

-= Kitchen =-
If you're wondering why everything seems so usual all of a sudden, it's because you've just shown up in the kitchen.

You make out a fridge. You make out a closed conventional looking oven here. You can make out a table. You wonder idly who left that here. The table is massive. On the table you can see a knife. Now that's what I call TextWorld! You can see a counter. Now why would someone leave that there? On the counter you make out a cookbook. You see a stove. But oh no! there's nothing on this piece of junk. Hm. Oh well

There is a closed frosted-glass door leading south. There is a closed screen door leading west. You need an exit without a door? You should try going east.


>
(I see exits to the south, west, and east. I finally found the kitchen, so now I should check the cookbook for the recipe.) READ COOKBOOK

You open the copy of "Cooking: A Modern Approach (3rd Ed.)" and start reading:

Recipe #1
---------
Gather all following ingredients and follow the directions to prepare this tasty meal.

Ingredients:
green hot pepper
  red tuna
  white tuna

Directions:
slice the green hot pepper
  fry the green hot pepper
  chop the red tuna
  fry the red tuna
  chop the white tuna
  fry the white tuna
  prepare meal



>
(I need to gather the ingredients. Let me first check my current inventory.) I

You are carrying: a green hot pepper, a green bell pepper and a yellow bell pepper.


>

(I see I'm already carrying a green hot pepper, which is one of the ingredients I need. I also have some unnecessary items, a green bell pepper and a yellow bell pepper. I should drop those since I don't need them for this recipe.) DROP GREEN BELL PEPPER

You drop the green bell pepper on the ground.


>
(I've dropped the green bell pepper. Now I should also drop the yellow bell pepper, as it's not needed for this recipe either.) DROP YELLOW BELL PEPPER

You drop the yellow bell pepper on the ground.


>
(I've dropped the yellow bell pepper. Now my inventory should only have the green hot pepper. Let me check.) I

You are carrying: a green hot pepper.


>

(I only have the green hot pepper, which is one of the ingredients. Now I need to find the red tuna and the white tuna. Let's explore the kitchen and surrounding areas to see if I can find them.) OPEN FRIDGE

You open the fridge, revealing a raw red tuna, a raw red potato and a raw pork chop.


>
(I found the raw red tuna, which is one of the ingredients I need. I should pick it up.) GET RAW RED TUNA

You take the red tuna from the fridge.


Your score has just gone up by one point.

>
(I now have the green hot pepper and the raw red tuna. I still need to find the white tuna. Let me check the fridge again to see if I missed it.) OPEN FRIDGE
